We are net very fond of visiting Courts
of Justice (civil or crimlnaD and rarely go
there except to listen to some noble exer-
tion of the human intellect, or to witness
some rare display of human wickedness.,-
Saturday was "sentence day" and those who
ike to study moral curiosties will find it a
place where much amusement may be gain
ed and some useful lessons learned.


vast apartment is crowded with dele
gates from every order of society. Men Of
all ages, professions and classes--of every
degree Of honesty aud vice, from the unsus-
pected integrity Of the judge, down through
regular gradations, to the convict, black and
loathsome with crime: some attracted from
idle curiosity, some from business, some
from an anxious interest in tine fate of their
unhappy relatives, and some from Il still
more fearful interest in the fortune Of tAel
guilty associates; an enormous throng o! al
complexions, and displaying all possible va
rieties of dress, from the ragged, sbiltless


shoeless mendicant, to the spruce and per
fumed coxcomb-weeping females, lawyers
jurors, judges. reporters, constables, &c, &c
make up the motley audience Of session

1NE SESSIONS.

The packet ship Coun.bia, II New York
brings London papers to the evening of the
18th March inclusive. We copy the follow
ing items:


The ! IVA Packet, from Batavia, went
down off Flushing, and the whole OF her
crew. consisting Of so souls, were doomed
to watery grave. with the exception of
the pilot. who contrived to save himself
She had OH board eight thousand bags o..
coffee, which are ali gone. She was insured
at Iloyd's.


The British ship Marmon, Capt. Petrie.
from Liverpool to Calcutta, with a cargo
valued at from 50 TO 100000, was abandon
ed at sea, on the 18th of February, having
started butt, the crew and passengers were
saved by the British ship Garland.


Courtney, the American, who had previ-
ouslv announced that he would take ''ter
rife fight at Bath" from Beechin Cliff over
the Ole Bridge, disappointed some thousands
of persons who had congregated to witness
this scnseess and dangerous exploit-the
rope was either broken or cat, and the ex-
pertinent was deferred.

1t was confidently reported in London on
the 18th Of March. that Sir II. Clinton has
written home in the strongest terms for re-
Inducements. The gallant general, it is
said, has declared 5000 additional troops ne
cessary.


Madrid papers of the 22d Feb. state that
several British regiments had been engaged
with the Portuguese royalists, and had beat
en- them. The aid-tle-camp of Gen. Clinton
was killed in the action.


Affairs in Portugal are not quite settled;
it was reported that the rebels had taken
possession ot Oporto, but il is not positively
affirmed. War is not expected. Some SEN
sation was felt in the manufacturing towns
on the subject of an additional duty on wool


The alarming Illness of Lord Liverpool,
(and the indispositon of MIR. Cannng) have
greatly impeded the public business. Ihe
Courier (Which speaks from anthority,l says
that even if the noble Earl should recover
the resumption of his duties rs Prince Min
lister cannot be expected. A total cessation
from all mental exe'tion will be necessary

BY the Colossus, arrived at New York
from Havana information is received that
Commodore Porter was still at Key West.
and that the Spanish and Mexican squadrons
lay in sight of each other. The Commo-
dnre's force consisted of a ship and two briggs,
as formerly. and consequently, (says the n.
i. Daily AdveItiser) the report by the YES
sci from Xibara relative to the latter is un-
founded. The account Of the capture OF
Commodore Porter's first officer is confirm
ed. He had taken coaster aud was max
ing for Key West, when he WAS pursued;
and was Obliged to run his prize vessel a.
shore With five of his own men and fifteen
prisoners, he got into the long boat, when
the latter overpowerel him, and thus he vas
taken.
FROM KEY WEST.

Tie third victory gained by kariskahi, is
confirmed. The booty taken at Nolllzza was
much more considerable than at first report
ed. Salona is in the hands Of the Greeks
Kariskakl, after his victories at Arakova
and Noli,Aa, where he took 1890 horses, all
kinds Of a,nmunitlons, provisions, surprised
and cat to pieces, near Lepanto, a corps Of
one Thousand Turks, who we're marching to
Salona to relieve that place. Part of KS
troops arc to be sent TO the army of Eleusis.
Two hundred Pelopponesians have already
repaired thither, and two Thousand men, un-
der Coils. Gordon aud Petromichallv, are 60
ing by sea to the Plrceus, escorted by the
american f1igatr, commanded by Miauis
All these forces united, are simultaneously
to attack the Seraskier Reaschid Pacha,
had approached Athens, from which he
retired in consequence of the victory of Ar
okoya, thus giving Col. Fabvier an opportu-
nifty to enter the Acropols with ammuni-
tons and provisions.


Accounts had been received at Prersa,
that two vessels, laden with provisions, were
at Petala, waiting orders from karaiskaki;
and that Mokry had made him self master Of
Stamnias, near Mssolonghl.


These favourable circumstances, saws a
letter to the Geneva Greek Committee,
prove how useful cur consignments of pro-
visions have been; since the Greeks have
thereby been enabled TO resume offensive o,.-
erations.

BY the last accounts the stupendous nroiect of
excavating Tunnel, or passage way for Carra.
ges and travellers, under the Ricey Thames at
London, was proceeding with great rapdty and
success. The distance excavated was 400 feet
from the shaft, and the workment were engaged
270 feet undertlle river. The most formidable
obstrctions anticipated, viz: the land Springs or
quick sands, had been surlnounted. The work
people are relieved every eight hours. The
company could beneiically employ more hands
than offer themselves, but there still existed ma
ny ignorant working people, who thought they
must encounter extraordinary danger of being
engnlphed by the river, if they engaged in this
underwater employment.

On the fonrth nf March. there was most
extraordinary fail of snow in Scotland
There lad not been 50 great a fall, in so
short period oi tune, since February, 1899,
when parts q IT, Whicl, got into hollows and
against waits, remained uudissovcd i'll June.
1t was expected 70 li: highly disastrous to

THE AUTHOR OF THE WANERLY


NOVELS.


II is with no ordinary degree Of satisfaction
that we announce the fact that Sir Walter
scott has confessed himself to be the entire
and sole author of the Waverly Novels. The
secret was directly and finally divulged at
the Edinburgh Theatrical Fund Dinner, on
Friday, the eth of February. In reply to
his health being proposed by Lord Meadow
bank:---


"5ir Walter Scott said he did not expect
to have revealed before three hundred gem
tlemen a secret which had been remarkably
well kept for great number o. years-(A
langh) THOUGH he might have been put on
trial for the offence Of which he stood con-
victed before Lord Meadowbank, yet an IN
tclligent and impartial Jury would consider
the evidence before they gave the verdict a
gainst him, they might perhaps give ver-
dict Of not troren-( (laughtcr,) and not to
enter into the reasons which determined him
to keep 50 long silence; perhaps caprice
1 had a great share iii 1t; the tault he entire
| " imputed to hinisclt indeed, he vas afraid
to think what he had now duHc-look at it
again, he dared not. But as tats would go
ont to the public, he meant i to go serious
H., when he said that he was the total and
unt!iviled author q these noyels---there was
not single word wiltten, except some quo
tatien OF suggestion made, which was not
his own, or what he had found in his own
reading. .--.C Much cheering He would now
propose, in the capacity Of author of these
EDNGIS, tilt bSdlll VI ENlliShiib vi tuio
company, he meant his friend Balie Nicol
Iarve, they wnnla al recolect the applause
he received at the theatre, aud they would, no
doubt, lie inclined to give him some here.
.oud cletrinp.l "rhs health Of Baltic Nj
col larQie." Mr.. Mackay, after short
pause, exclaimel-" My conscience My
worthy father, the Deacon. had he been in
existence, would IA have believed that sic
can great honor should betal me, his son--
that should nave had such compliment
paid me by the Great Unknown. ! have
borne my civic ,ouors FOR eight years, and
} trust that none Of my brethren in the coun-
Gil haze given more satisfaction (Much
) laughter,1 Before sit down, beg leave to
propose the health ot "l'hc Lord Provost
and Magistrates of Fdinbuigh hi Nouti
cheers.l Air al was within 4 mile Of Ed
burgh."

full articles.headline:
lr9a NE At7v York Enquirer.


1NE SESSIONS.
full articles.article:
We are net very fond of visiting Courts
of Justice (civil or crimlnaD and rarely go
there except to listen to some noble exer-
tion of the human intellect, or to witness
some rare display of human wickedness.,-
Saturday was "sentence day" and those who
ike to study moral curiosties will find it a
place where much amusement may be gain
ed and some useful lessons learned.


vast apartment is crowded with dele
gates from every order of society. Men Of
all ages, professions and classes--of every
degree Of honesty aud vice, from the unsus-
pected integrity Of the judge, down through
regular gradations, to the convict, black and
loathsome with crime: some attracted from
idle curiosity, some from business, some
from an anxious interest in tine fate of their
unhappy relatives, and some from Il still
more fearful interest in the fortune Of tAel
guilty associates; an enormous throng o! al
complexions, and displaying all possible va
rieties of dress, from the ragged, sbiltless


shoeless mendicant, to the spruce and per
fumed coxcomb-weeping females, lawyers
jurors, judges. reporters, constables, &c, &c
make up the motley audience Of session

full articles.headline: T0RE1e5T9 Z7l:rx.l1..E.assNMCE.
full articles.article:
The packet ship Coun.bia, II New York
brings London papers to the evening of the
18th March inclusive. We copy the follow
ing items:


The ! IVA Packet, from Batavia, went
down off Flushing, and the whole OF her
crew. consisting Of so souls, were doomed
to watery grave. with the exception of
the pilot. who contrived to save himself
She had OH board eight thousand bags o..
coffee, which are ali gone. She was insured
at Iloyd's.


The British ship Marmon, Capt. Petrie.
from Liverpool to Calcutta, with a cargo
valued at from 50 TO 100000, was abandon
ed at sea, on the 18th of February, having
started butt, the crew and passengers were
saved by the British ship Garland.


Courtney, the American, who had previ-
ouslv announced that he would take ''ter
rife fight at Bath" from Beechin Cliff over
the Ole Bridge, disappointed some thousands
of persons who had congregated to witness
this scnseess and dangerous exploit-the
rope was either broken or cat, and the ex-
pertinent was deferred.

full articles.headline: PORTUGAL AND SPAIN.
full articles.article:
1t was confidently reported in London on
the 18th Of March. that Sir II. Clinton has
written home in the strongest terms for re-
Inducements. The gallant general, it is
said, has declared 5000 additional troops ne
cessary.


Madrid papers of the 22d Feb. state that
several British regiments had been engaged
with the Portuguese royalists, and had beat
en- them. The aid-tle-camp of Gen. Clinton
was killed in the action.


Affairs in Portugal are not quite settled;
it was reported that the rebels had taken
possession ot Oporto, but il is not positively
affirmed. War is not expected. Some SEN
sation was felt in the manufacturing towns
on the subject of an additional duty on wool


The alarming Illness of Lord Liverpool,
(and the indispositon of MIR. Cannng) have
greatly impeded the public business. Ihe
Courier (Which speaks from anthority,l says
that even if the noble Earl should recover
the resumption of his duties rs Prince Min
lister cannot be expected. A total cessation
from all mental exe'tion will be necessary

full articles.headline: FROM KEY WEST.
full articles.article:
BY the Colossus, arrived at New York
from Havana information is received that
Commodore Porter was still at Key West.
and that the Spanish and Mexican squadrons
lay in sight of each other. The Commo-
dnre's force consisted of a ship and two briggs,
as formerly. and consequently, (says the n.
i. Daily AdveItiser) the report by the YES
sci from Xibara relative to the latter is un-
founded. The account Of the capture OF
Commodore Porter's first officer is confirm
ed. He had taken coaster aud was max
ing for Key West, when he WAS pursued;
and was Obliged to run his prize vessel a.
shore With five of his own men and fifteen
prisoners, he got into the long boat, when
the latter overpowerel him, and thus he vas
taken.

AN ACT TO grant quantity of land 70 tic


State of Illinois, for the purpose Of aiding IL


opening a Canal 10 connect the watc. Of


the Illinois River with those Of the Lake Mich


igan.


Be il enacted On the Senate and ffoUac 9f
RehresentatipeS Of the United Slate& Of "
merica in Congress aSScmbled. That there
be, and hereby is, granted TO the State Gf Hi
nos, for the purpose ofading the State in open-
ing canal to unite the waters Of the Illinois iiv-
er with those of Lake Michigan, quantity Of
land equal to one half Of five sections in width,
on each side Of said canal, and reserving each
alternate section to the United States, TO be Sc
lected by the Commissioner Of the Land Office,
under the direction Of the President nf the Unit
ed States, from one end Of the said Canal 10 the
other; and the said lands shall be subject 70 the
disposal of the Legislature Of the said State, for
the purpose aforesaid, and no other; PyomdW,
That the said canal, when completed, shall be-,
and forever remain, public highway for the use
Of the Government Of the e. States, free from a.
ny toll, or other charge, whatever, for any prop
crty of the u States, or persons in their service,
passing through the same. Propdod, that said
canal shall be commenced within five Years and
completed in twenty years, or the State shall be
bound to pay to the United states the amount OF
any lands previously sold, and that the title to
purchasers under the State shall he VOID.


src. ?. find be HJarfher eaaefed, That, so
soon as the route oftlie said canal shall be ocat-
cd and agreed on BY the said state, It shall be
the duty Of the Governor thereof. or such Other
person or persons as may have been, or shall
hereafter be, authorizedt to sllperintcnd the con
struction Of said canal to examine and ascertain
/ the particular sections 10 which the said State
will be entitled under the provisions OF this act
and report She same to the Secretary Of the
1 Treasury.


:, slr, B. ,At@ BE i J,Utter enacted, That The

Approved March ?, 1927.

,siier BROOKS, that is, not to make any snole
mic. ,kes about black 6Qils; tor though II Is
below gentleman to call HIN out, ! "lii
find other manes of giving him bag-fuli OF
broken bones.


The me .,bers now saw that there was no.
thing for It, but to send the intruder to 60
yentry, which they appeared to oby tacit
ayreement; for when Admiral Stewart de-
oartei. Which he did almost Immediately,
ur. Fitzgerald found himself completely cW
Nv al! ..his dear friends" The gentlemen
gov formed themselves into groups at the
several whist tables; and m one chose 10 re-
ply to his observations, nor 10 return even
nod to the toasts and healtbs whlcn ne
drank, whilst discussing three botues OF the
sparkling liquor which the tcmiiled waiter
placed before hitnn succession. AZ length,
hndiny that no one would communicate with
him in either kind, either for drinking or
fighting, he arose, AMI making a low bow,
fool, his leave as follows :--Gentlemen |
bid YOU all good night: | am very glad to
find We so soriable: I'll take care to come ear
lier neat night, and wen have a little more
if it, hlaSe God"


The departure of the bully was great re-
lief to every one present, for the restraint
caused By his vapouring and insoleEt behav-
iour was most ilMolerab.e. The conversation
Immediately became general, and it was
unanimously agreed tina. half a dozen stout
constables should be in waiting the next e
vening to take him by tho heels and bear him
off to The watch house, if he attempted again
to intrude. OF some such measure tit2se-
raid seemed to be aware; for he never show
ed himself at Brooke's again. though he
boasted every where that he had been unaH
inousy chosen member OF the club!

sentenGe .slay.-- rhe yea business u thc
court is, TO a strange aud philanthropist,
highly interesting. The FIRST thing IS 'fhe
discharges" Fifty orsiAty miserable wretch
es are called up AMI ranged outside OF the
bar, without any regard to sex, age or color
here a thick-lipped African, there pallid
prostitute, in tadedsplendor; there sturdy
vagrant, with hlar ike tallow candles, and
trow sers that disdiin their office; next
greyheaded culprit trying to hide his inta-
my behind the brawny shoulders OF WICK
ed looking ruffian ofnineteen with copious
sprnkling of negre wenches, exhibiting
curious specimen of he strange company IN
to which vice and misery bring their VIC
TINS. This gang is then discharged by
proclamation, and they vanish III an instant.
| Then come the persons convicted of ttie
more serious crimes. They arc brought up
in pairs, and the Recorder very briefly re-
capitulates their offence, and pronounces
their sentence. Occasionally the unhappy
culprits make an appeal to the mercy OF the
court. On Saturday there were two lhstan-
ces where the prisoners appealed very pow
erfully and atEectingly to the humanity OF the
Jldge. The first was young and good
looking Irishman, who had pleaded "gnilty"





money by means OF forged drat. upon the
| North River Bank. lie admitted his crime,
and gave short history of his life, as ground
for asking some modification of his sentence.
He had been about year in the country,
and had exhausted all his means in vain
attempt to obtain some permanent employ.
ri family in Ireland was respectable, and
his own character had hitherto been unim-
peachcd. II know" said he, "that in my
country. such a crime would have been eX-
plated with my death. ask no mitigation
OF nv sentence here, deserve to be pun
ished, and | submit. But do not--oh do
I not send me to niingle with the wckedness
and proiligacy Of the common prison, as my
principles aud my heart are untainted. and
] would be spared the temptations and the
poutions Of such ycons communion. Put
me in solitary confinement; send me to death;
! be let me shot at once, SO that my name may
never more be heard of. and my family and
friends may be spared the story OF my
shame." but justice was inexorable, and
the poor fellow was sentenced to seven years


ha.tl labor il the state prison. The other


was case Of still greater intcr,t.


A we'll dressed, Well educated. aud well


bern young man was placed ct the bar, cott-


yictetl oshaving been engaged with two boYS


ia the commission Of some petty felony. His
{ address to theFcourt was long vehement, pa


thesic and eloquent He very ski!flliy re-


viewed the evidence, and the examined facts


which appeared against him with the vain


hope Of obtaing a new trial, and then pray


ed the lent, Of the court on the ground q
I his misfortuncs and his sutlerinEs. lie stat


ed that he was actually the plaintiff in .


chanccry suit against his brother-in-law ioi
5..t
the sum Of gil, Geo, aud that his aged moth
; er had been dragged from his arms and col-
fined in mad house. Ills address was eX-


tremviy we'll worled, and was very impress


lively delivered. 1t eyinced large share d


talents The court, however, was deal tc
his ntreaties, and sentenced him to three
wears in the state prison. It seems he ha!


already been there. Fer one female, we irl


no little anxiety She was an Irshwoman


neatty dressed, Of very respectable appear
ance, aged a. and tie mother of s children
i The children are At Boston, and her hus
: band "a sailnr) is hourly expected from sea
f 1t appeared that this woman obtained stu
0 alton as a servant in one of those vile recep


tacles of sin which are permitted to eXis
. even in the respectable streets Of our CITY,
: As soon as She discovered the character o
the place. She wished 10 quit it, bat her mis-
!, treSs refused to pay hei wages. The poo
y woman then took some articles Of furniture
. as security TIL She would get her money
" This was her ciiHt, and the recorder il
passing sentence, save her strong hopes {
. speedy pardon from the governor On


tall Eaunt Iiiberninn amused us q rreat deal
. He was sentenced to SIX months hard labo
c in the penitentiarv.--" Could not your excel
o lency", said he in perfect sincerity, "contriv
Z to alter it to three months i'll one Of til
a states vessels"


II

full articles.headline: GREECE.
full articles.article:
Tie third victory gained by kariskahi, is
confirmed. The booty taken at Nolllzza was
much more considerable than at first report
ed. Salona is in the hands Of the Greeks
Kariskakl, after his victories at Arakova
and Noli,Aa, where he took 1890 horses, all
kinds Of a,nmunitlons, provisions, surprised
and cat to pieces, near Lepanto, a corps Of
one Thousand Turks, who we're marching to
Salona to relieve that place. Part of KS
troops arc to be sent TO the army of Eleusis.
Two hundred Pelopponesians have already
repaired thither, and two Thousand men, un-
der Coils. Gordon aud Petromichallv, are 60
ing by sea to the Plrceus, escorted by the
american f1igatr, commanded by Miauis
All these forces united, are simultaneously
to attack the Seraskier Reaschid Pacha,
had approached Athens, from which he
retired in consequence of the victory of Ar
okoya, thus giving Col. Fabvier an opportu-
nifty to enter the Acropols with ammuni-
tons and provisions.


Accounts had been received at Prersa,
that two vessels, laden with provisions, were
at Petala, waiting orders from karaiskaki;
and that Mokry had made him self master Of
Stamnias, near Mssolonghl.


These favourable circumstances, saws a
letter to the Geneva Greek Committee,
prove how useful cur consignments of pro-
visions have been; since the Greeks have
thereby been enabled TO resume offensive o,.-
erations.

brokeu. The Young nan VINO was enployea
grinding tho powder was considerably injured,
and had been forced out Of the building. After
viewing the effects Of the explosion, III the de-
,tructon of the room and the various artcles,
we were surprised that the young man was
not more severely injured, and that the scenery
which was close to the room, had not been set
ON firc but strange as it may appear, no fire was
visible after the smoke had cleared away. The
accident must have been caused by spark from
n stove, which was near the powders


A letter from Liberia, dated at Monrovia, Feb.
5th says

full articles.headline: THAMES TUNNEL.
full articles.article:
BY the last accounts the stupendous nroiect of
excavating Tunnel, or passage way for Carra.
ges and travellers, under the Ricey Thames at
London, was proceeding with great rapdty and
success. The distance excavated was 400 feet
from the shaft, and the workment were engaged
270 feet undertlle river. The most formidable
obstrctions anticipated, viz: the land Springs or
quick sands, had been surlnounted. The work
people are relieved every eight hours. The
company could beneiically employ more hands
than offer themselves, but there still existed ma
ny ignorant working people, who thought they
must encounter extraordinary danger of being
engnlphed by the river, if they engaged in this
underwater employment.

THE AUTHOR OF THE WANERLY


NOVELS.


II is with no ordinary degree Of satisfaction
that we announce the fact that Sir Walter
scott has confessed himself to be the entire
and sole author of the Waverly Novels. The
secret was directly and finally divulged at
the Edinburgh Theatrical Fund Dinner, on
Friday, the eth of February. In reply to
his health being proposed by Lord Meadow
bank:---


"5ir Walter Scott said he did not expect
to have revealed before three hundred gem
tlemen a secret which had been remarkably
well kept for great number o. years-(A
langh) THOUGH he might have been put on
trial for the offence Of which he stood con-
victed before Lord Meadowbank, yet an IN
tclligent and impartial Jury would consider
the evidence before they gave the verdict a
gainst him, they might perhaps give ver-
dict Of not troren-( (laughtcr,) and not to
enter into the reasons which determined him
to keep 50 long silence; perhaps caprice
1 had a great share iii 1t; the tault he entire
| " imputed to hinisclt indeed, he vas afraid
to think what he had now duHc-look at it
again, he dared not. But as tats would go
ont to the public, he meant i to go serious
H., when he said that he was the total and
unt!iviled author q these noyels---there was
not single word wiltten, except some quo
tatien OF suggestion made, which was not
his own, or what he had found in his own
reading. .--.C Much cheering He would now
propose, in the capacity Of author of these
EDNGIS, tilt bSdlll VI ENlliShiib vi tuio
company, he meant his friend Balie Nicol
Iarve, they wnnla al recolect the applause
he received at the theatre, aud they would, no
doubt, lie inclined to give him some here.
